nodes.text: Prudence? What does prudence have to do with the ability of the people to freely exercise their constitutionally recognized and protected rights?
So you would like pre-teens to have open access to buy, carry and use firearms? The prudence is because them exercising their 'rights' can lead to someone else being deprived of all of theirs.
That sounds more than a little paraniod.
And you just sound ignorant. You wouldn't make this statement if you knew about how Britain's current gun control laws came into existence.

You/he could just have said 'slippery slope' in the first place; that argument is an old one, which I though was dealt with a long time ago. You can't disapprove of A on the grounds that it might lead to B - firstly because you have little to no evidence that it will, secondly because A is not necessary for B to happen and thirdly because that difference between A and B is all the argument you need to prevent B but be in favour of A. You can approve of punishing criminals but be against the death sentance.
